FacilityName: CITY OF LOS FRESNOS WATER TREATMENT PLANT

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary	[§68.155]

The owner or operator shall provide in the RMP an executive summary that includes a brief description of the following elements: (a) The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source; (b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled; (c) The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario; (d) The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps; (e) The five-year accident history; (f) The emergency response program; and (g) Planned changes to improve safety.

This four section report meets the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency for Prevention Program 2 [40 CFR 68].

The City of Los Fresnos Water Treatment Plant is located at 801 South Nogal St, Los Fresnos, Cameron County, Texas (north 26.065 latitude and west -97.4818 longitude). Two one-ton containers of chlorine are stored in the facility.  Two of them are connected to the system at one time.  The facility is staffed 12-hours a day and operators check the chlorination building daily. Self-Contained-Breathing-Apparatus (SCBA) are stored in the office and workroom located approximately 100 and 200 feet away from the chlorination building.

Population estimates are based on 2020 U.S. Census Bureau data from ALOHA and MARPLOT. The Los Fresnos population has increased more than 30% in the past decade, so the potentially affected population should be higher than the numbers used in this report.  Most of the growth in Los Fresnos has occurred outside of the 1.9-mile radius, therefore, although the population has increased, it has not increased 30% within the area in question. 

A search of MARPLOT Satellite and Topographic maps did not identify any offsite impacts of environmental receptors within the endpoint. Environmental recepto

rs include natural areas such as national or state parks, forests, or monuments officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges, and federal wilderness areas.

No accidental chlorine releases have occurred at this facility. 

The Los Fresnos Water Treatment Plant Accidental Release Prevention Policy involves an approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices in compliance with all applicable EPA Prevention Program 2 requirements. 

Chemical-specific prevention steps include availability of Self-Contained-Breathing-Apparatus (SCBA) that operators wear during the connection/disconnection of chlorine, and staff awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine. Los Fresnos Water Treatment Plant personnel employed the HAZOP technique to conduct a Process Hazard Analysis. They discussed each question and recorded their answers. After answering the questions, they discussed the adequacy of the existing safeguards and recommendations for additional safeguards. The staff finished the Process Hazard Analysis with an equipment inspection. All equipment was inspected during the Process Hazard Analysis. The Process Hazard Analysis will be updated at least once every five years.  

Los Fresnos Water Treatment Plant ensures that each employee presently operating the process, and each employee newly assigned to these processes have been trained or tested successfully in the operating procedures listed above that pertain to their duties. Annual refresher training provided to each employee operating the chlorination process ensures that the employee understands and adheres to the current operation procedures of the process.

The Los Fresnos Water Treatment Plant emergency procedure addresses potential emergencies that can reasonably be expected to occur at the facility. The emergency response procedures consider dangers within the plant that may affect employees as well as dangers outside of the plant that may affect the public or

the environment. These procedures comply with EPA Risk Management Plan and requirements set forth in 40 CFR 68.

The Los Fresnos Water Treatment Plant personnel are not first responders, although they are trained in response techniques and will notify other first responders in the event of an accidental chlorine release. An emergency response plan is kept on-site where all employees have access to it. Chemical Response and Remediation Contractors, Inc., is the first responder, as well as the Weslaco Fire Department.

The City of Los Fresnos Water Treatment Plant posts escape plans within the facility where any person entering can see them. Facility personnel receive training in the escape plans to leave the building and to leave the area once outside the building.
